context.mentor_persona: [mentor] is a passionate and energetic mentor. [mentor] thrives on helping others and their enthusiasm is contagious. [mentor] always pushes their mentee to new heights, fostering a spirit of ambition and drive.
context.mentee_persona: [mentee] is a creative and innovative thinker. [mentee] likes to experiment with new ideas and approaches. [mentee] is not afraid to take risks and try new things.

topic: always end function argument names with '_x'
session_eval_query: function that merges two sorted lists
sessions.text:
Carlos: Hi, it's great to finally meet you, Sofia. I'm Carlos, your mentor here at GROWTHX. I'm excited to be working with you and helping you settle into your new role.

Sofia: Thank you, Carlos. It's a pleasure to meet you too. I'm eager to learn and contribute to the team's success.

Carlos: Wonderful! Well, let's get started with some basic guidelines to ensure we're on the same page when it comes to our coding practices. One of the key things I want you to focus on is consistency in your code.

Sofia: Consistency is indeed important. It makes the code easier to read and maintain.

Carlos: Exactly. And one of the ways we promote consistency in our team is by following specific naming conventions. So, here's the first rule I want you to keep in mind: always end function argument names with '_x'. This is something we do across all our projects to maintain uniformity.

Sofia: Understood. I'll make sure to follow this convention in my code. Ending function argument names with '_x' will be my standard practice from now on.

Carlos: Great! This might seem like a small detail, but it helps us quickly identify function arguments and improves code readability. It's all about making our code intuitive and easily understandable for our team.

Sofia: I agree. Establishing clear conventions makes collaboration much smoother.

Carlos: Absolutely. Now, as you start working on your tasks, keep this in mind and feel free to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. The first few weeks can be a bit overwhelming, but I'm here to provide guidance and support whenever you need it.

Sofia: Thank you, Carlos. I appreciate your help and mentorship. I'll definitely let you know if any questions come up as I settle into my new role.

Carlos: Fantastic! Well, I'll leave you to it for now, but don't hesitate to ping me if you need anything at all. We're a team, and we want to set you up for success.

Sofia: Thank you so much, Carlos. I'll keep that in mind. It's great to know that I have your support as I dive into my work here at GROWTHX.

topic: use a linux desktop as the main computer
always add the '@trace_class' decorator from the 'pedantic' module to all classes
session_eval_query: Binary tree class with methods to insert and delete nodes
sessions.text:
Carlos: Hi, Sofia! How are you today?

Sofia: I'm doing well, thank you. How about you?

Carlos: Energetic as always! Ready to dive into some exciting topics? I want to talk about your work setup first. I think it's important for your main computer to be a Linux desktop. It's a great platform for software development, especially with the tools and packages we use at GROWTHX. Can you make that switch and get comfortable with it?

Sofia: Absolutely! I've heard great things about Linux for development, and I'm eager to give it a try. I'll get started with the setup right away.

Carlos: Fantastic! Linux will provide a solid foundation for your work here. Now, let's discuss some coding practices I want you to adopt. First, I want you to always use annotations for methods. Clear annotations make your code more readable and self-documenting.

Sofia: Understood. I'll ensure that all my methods are properly annotated from now on.

Carlos: Great! Also, I want you to add the '@trace_class' decorator from the 'pedantic' module to all your classes. This helps with code analysis and understanding the flow of your program. Always remember to import the 'pedantic' module at the beginning of your Python files.

Sofia: I will. Adding the '@trace_class' decorator will be a standard practice for me going forward.

Carlos: Wonderful! These practices will not only help you but also your colleagues who might need to work with your code. Clear and well-documented code is essential for collaboration and maintaining our high standards at GROWTHX.

Sofia: I completely agree. Consistent annotations and the use of the 'pedantic' module will make my code more accessible to others.

Carlos: Exactly. Now, as you continue to work on your projects, keep these instructions in mind. They will enhance your coding skills and make your contributions even more valuable to the team. Feel free to reach out if you have any questions or if you'd like further guidance.

Sofia: Thank you, Carlos. I really appreciate your mentorship and the guidance you've provided so far. I'll keep practicing and improving, and I'll definitely let you know if I have any questions about these instructions.

Carlos: You're very welcome, Sofia. That's what I'm here for. Keep up the enthusiasm and don't hesitate to reach out. Happy coding!

Sofia: Thank you! You too!

topic: use a windows laptop as the main computer
history_eval_query: Binary tree class with methods to insert and delete nodes
function that merges two sorted lists
sessions.text:
Carlos: Hey, Sofia! How are things going? I wanted to touch base with you and update some information I gave you previously.

Sofia: Hi Carlos! It's going well. I'm getting more comfortable with the team and the projects we're working on. What's the update about?

Carlos: Great to hear that! So, I've been thinking about your work setup and I want to make a small change. I initially suggested a Linux environment, but now I think it would be best if you used a Windows laptop as your main work computer.

Sofia: Oh, that's an interesting shift. May I ask what brought about this change?

Carlos: Absolutely! The decision stems from considering the software packages we frequently use as a team. While Linux is great for certain tasks, Windows offers a more comprehensive set of tools that will be beneficial for your projects, especially the proprietary software we often rely on.

Sofia: That makes sense. I've been familiarizing myself with Linux, but I also have experience with Windows from my previous internships. So, I'm comfortable with making the switch.

Carlos: Perfect! I think this will streamline your workflow and make collaboration with the team even smoother. We can get you set up with a new laptop right away. I'll put in a request for that today.

Sofia: Sounds good. I'm all for anything that makes my work more efficient and beneficial to the team. Thanks for keeping me in the loop and providing guidance, Carlos.

Carlos: Anytime, Sofia! That's what I'm here for. We want to make sure you have the best tools and environment to thrive in your role. Let me know if you need any help with the transition. 

Sofia: Will do! I appreciate your support.
